thread.title: JURUPA VALLEY: Chip the husky adopted by police officer
thread.title_full: JURUPA VALLEY: Chip the husky adopted by police officer - Press Enterprise

author: MICHAEL WATANABE
title: JURUPA VALLEY: Chip the husky adopted by police officer
text:
BY MICHAEL WATANABE / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 14, 2015 Updated: 11:15 p.m. JURUPA VALLEY: Chip the husky adopted by police officer Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 2 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Chip the husky greets his new owner Mike Ventura, a Covina resident who is a Los Angeles Police Department officer. Chip was a passenger in a West Covina-to-Fontana pursuit in mid-September that was prompted by the wounding of a California Highway Patrol officer. (COURTESY OF RIVERSIDE COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF ANIMAL SERVICES) Related article » RELATED LAKE MATHEWS: Man rappels down 100-foot mine shaft to rescue pit bull
Chip the husky and his new owner already have a lot in common.
Both have seen their share of crime.
The 7-month-old dog is going home to Covina resident Mike Ventura, of the Los Angeles Police Department, say Riverside County Department of Animal Services officials.
Chip was a passenger in a West Covina-to-Fontana pursuit in mid-September that was prompted by the wounding of a California Highway Patrol officer.
The gunfire erupted Sept. 11 during a pre-dawn traffic stop of a Cadillac Escalade in West Covina. The suspect fled, eventually ending up in a dirt field at Citrus Avenue and Arrow Route in Fontana.
The officer survived the shooting.
And, it seems, Ventura earned the dog's affection more easily than the process of adopting him.
Ventura was one of 75 applicants who wrote essays to earn the right to adopt Chip .
"His heartfelt words resonated with a team of employees here at the main shelter who helped select the adopter," said Animal Services spokesman John Welsh, in a written statement.�
